content.description: Follow crack and arete to top.
content.location: Crack left of Overhanging Corner

content.description: On the left side of the Guillotine Wall if facing the water. Climb the arrete from the bottom to the top (exit left of easier and better protected climbing at the top if need be).
content.location: Otter Cliffs - Guillotine Wall

content.description: A fun face climb with the crux being three quarters of the way up the cliff where the face becomes blank before reaching the next horizontal crack.
content.protection: Top rope from a trad anchor back about 15 feet. Largest cam was #3 which made a bomber placement. Other smaller cams to make the rest of your placements.
content.location: This route is located on the section of of Otter cliffs called 'Wonderwall' in the guide book. Starts to the right of 'Easy Corner' when your looking at the cliff.

content.description: This route starts in front of the overhang that is a little lower than chest height. There are nice starting hand holds for climbers of most heights however the first foot hold, although it's nice, is high which adds to the difficulty of the start. I saw many beginners borrowing the start of the neighbouring route 'In The Grove' located to the right but this may effect the grade.
content.protection: Fixed Anchors are perfect for top roping this route
content.location: This route is located on the section of of Otter cliffs called 'Wonderwall' in the guide book.

content.description: Pick your line up the highly featured exciting face and enjoy the crimpy non-crack moves. Many different lines canbe taken on this face although no two are independant or far from the climb's 5.9 grade.
content.protection: Maybe some small nuts, and some very small cams, but 99% of folks TR this one.
content.location: You can setup a TR anchor/rappel point anywhere from the left staple.

content.description: Climb face through an overlap.
content.location: Right of Rock Lobster

content.description: Climb past ledge to face and over a bulge.
content.location: Between an alcove and right facing corner.

content.description: Climb through crack system, left facing corner and small roof.
content.location: Left of Coppertone

content.description: Climb corner and face to the top
content.location: At right facing corner

content.description: Climb just right of the small triangular hole by the bigger one and finish through the arete.
content.location: Under small triangular hole

content.description: Follow offwidth, pass a roof to the arete.
content.location: At offwidth

content.description: Up corner and right and finish on Sober Seaman
content.location: Corner left of Sober Seaman

content.description: Climb the arete to the top.
content.location: The arete

content.description: Good thin and technical   the arete left of Flake
content.location: Just right of "In the Grove"   Left of "Flakes"

content.description: Follow the notch to the top.
content.location: Inside corner / notch between two arÃªtes.

content.description: Climb through a slot and blocky rock. Pass roof on right.
content.location: Left of Ebb and Flow

content.description:
Same start as Drunken Sailor: climb the shallow corner, with a side-pull on the left face, between The Great Chimney and Black Crack (or what's left of it). But about 2/3 of the way up, at the overlap, veer left and diagonal to the top.

 NOTE- See COMMENT by Eliot Coffey about the route description. Â R Hall Â ME Admin.
content.location: If top-roping this, you may want to place a directional at the overlap.

content.description: Work your way up and left to a ledge and continue inside corner to top.
content.location: Right side of wall

content.description: A great problem to warm up on and show off if others are watching.  It is pretty small, only about 4 simple moves and the rock is quite sharp and unforgiving.  The crux is a small dyno up to the top of the cliff, top-out after that.  All in all a real fun and easy problem
content.protection: pad and spotters highly recommended even though it is an easy problem the landing is quite sketchy.
content.location: Again, park at the first parking lot for Otter Cliffs and hike the trail.  After about 300 feet you will see a small inlet cove right underneath the trail.  Descend down into the cove, there are a few other "climbable" features but none of them really flesh out into a problem.  if you are looking at the sea this problem is in the far right hand corner of the cove.  The start is somewhat obvious, you must crouch matching both hands in a small crack at the base of rock.

content.description: Climb the arete to a ledge. Then follow arete / left side of face to the top.
content.location: Right of Drunken Sailor.

content.description: Climb corner to top.
content.location: Next inside corner left of Overhanging Corner

content.description: Climb face and ledges to top.
content.location: Left of Seabreeze

content.description: Climb up good edges and horizontals up the face right of a chimney to a small roof. Pull the roof and lie-back up a thin left leaning corner.
content.protection: Gear anchor. Maybe some webbing or some static line.
content.location: The South face of The Sea Stack.

content.description: Pass the crack and a corner to a face and top out.
content.location: By a diagonal crack

content.description: Start right of Overhanging Corner. Climb face to obvious ledge. Climb toward left end of long roof and pull to follow diagonal flake right to top.
Follow thin crack to top.
content.location: By the plaque

content.description: Start 7 ft right of Adair by the Sea. Climb up to the small roof and step left into a short left facing corner to an overlap. Traverse right on a horizontal then trend left on jugs to top out.
content.protection: Standard New England rack with a #3 camalot for the crux.    2 bolt anchor.

content.description:
M.P. Currently Lists 85+ routes at Otter Cliffs. Current guidebooks break up this huge area (huge in terms of # of routes) into several sub-areas.  

  These sub areas are generally considered:   [Sea Cave]    (No routes at the moment entered)  

  [Plaque Wall]    Engel Arete Â Jamcrack  

  [Mermaid Wall]    Greybeard Â State of Maine  

  [Amphitheater Left]    Otter Point Â Black Crack  

  [Amphitheater Right]    Submariner Â Guillemont Crack  

  [Seastack]    The Great Chimney Â Swing Time  

  [Yellow Wall]    Chockstone Chimney Â Yellow Wall  

  [Guillotine Alcove]    FishermanÂs Folly Â Crucifix  

  [Wonder Wall]    Easy Corner Â In the Groove  

  [Adair Wall]    Starfish Â Peak Performance

Start up moderate corner and enjoy stemming, squeezing, and straigh on crack work. Don't forget to look around on either face, good holds abound. 

  Climbable even when wet (top-rope)
content.protection: Sucks up pro, watch out for the end of the crack when it'll try to keep it forever.
content.location: Locate giant perched block from where you can see the sea stack. the climb comes up the corner right there, you can build an anchor or sling the block.

content.description: Follow crack. Pass a ledge and continue to top.
content.location: At vertical crack

content.description: Climb right of the arete to the top.NOTE COMMENT :Â Detached block noted about 2 body lengths from the top of the route. Loose! Â    (photo shows lose block)Â
content.location: Just right of the arete

content.description: Climb face, blocky steps and an open book to top.
content.location: Right of Ebb and Flow

content.description: Climb corner through roof. Go right and finish (shared with Spray Deck).
content.location: Right facing corner right of Guillotine

content.description: New route created by the recent rock fall at Otter Cliffs. Start off just right of over hanging corner and climb a vertical face to overhanging arete. Climb the left side of the arete on small crimps. This an atypical Otter route with a hard burly reach and height dependent crux. Much easier for the tall climber.
content.location: The arete climbers right of "Overhanging" corner and just left of where "Razor Flake" used to be.

content.description: Climb to ledge and through nice face to top.
content.location: Nice face left of arete

content.description: Climb face and pull through roof.
content.location: Between The Flake and A Dare by the Sea.

content.description: Climb thin rotten looking face and finish through roof.
content.location: Between arete on left and Guillotine on right.

content.description: Start the same as Summer Camp Corner but continue straight up the vertical crack.
content.location: Right side of wall

content.description: -crux is half way up   -if your tall it has one hard move, if short you'll get 2 hard moves
content.location: The Slab just left of Yellow Wall

content.description: Start up the obvious flake that borders Wonder Wall, enjoy the variety of moves that can be used to gain the top of this fun moderate flake.
content.location: Off the middle staple, just right(climber's right) of the Wonder Wall

content.description: A good adventure bound to get some funny looks! This is a left to right girdle traverse that can be done anywhere from 6-10 pitches. The climb starts at the Escape Hatch and follows  generally easy blocky terrain within half to two-thirds height of the cliff  crawling around the sea stack (super cool)  and ending on a Dare By the Sea (5.10d). We found the most exciting part of the climb was from Razor Back to Drunken Sailor with options of traversing high through sharp questionable blocks, or low with minimal gear and ground fall potential.
content.location: Start at the Escape Hatch far climbers left of the cliff.

content.description: Follow the wide crack using faceholds and intermittent thin cracks to the upper dihedral crux.  After a funky move or two to get the lieback, move slightly left into the roof and finish with a fantastic overhanging traverse to the right.
content.protection: Standard light rack (with an emphasis on smaller gear) or TR setup.
content.location: When facing the cliff, walk rightwards from the sea stack to a large right facing dihedral.  On the left wall of the dihedral, find a wide (~12 in.) crack that leads up into a chalked up roof.  There is usually a pool of water right below the base of the climb (although you can approach and belay from the left in relative dryness.)

content.description: On the left side of the Amphitheater if facing the water, right next to the Sea Stack, climb the corner and crack that stays just left of the chimney if facing the rock.
content.location: Otter Cliffs - Amphitheater Right

content.description: Climb corner, past ledge and follow grey streak.
content.location: Leftmost corner

content.description: Climb up right of the triangular hole and through a green streak.
content.location: Right of a small triangular hole.

content.description:
The obvious chimney between otter cliffs and the sea stack on which Rock Lobster is located on.  

  Classic & Fun
content.protection: Medium to small cams will do for building your top rope anchor
content.location: Climbers left between the cliff and the big sea stack.

content.description: Crimp, edge, lie-back, and smear up the steep technical face past a small roof to crux on opposing layback hold and straight up to top.
content.protection: Toprope. Gear anchor can be found with some ease.
content.location: The West face of The Sea Stack.

content.description: The blunt arete between The Great Chimney and Rock Lobster.
content.protection: Usually top-roped.  I don't think there is any decent pro on the upper face, which is about 2/5 of the climb.
content.location: Near the southwest corner of The Great Chimney's sea stack.

content.description: Follow right of arete and finish going around the roof on its left.
content.location: Just right of the arete

content.description:
I believe this route used to be a named 5.11d, but cannot find it anywhere. Â It has a beautifully overhanging, chunky, dynamic start and a wicked crimpy face to top, all separated by a flexy roof move.

 "I climbed this with Steve-the chimney sweep in '97 and returned 10/2019 with my son & friend. Â It did not look like it had been climbed since '97 and I did not see it listed on Mtn Project. Â If anyone else has climbed this route and/or would like to edit my post, please feel free"
content.location: This route is in the alcove behind the sea-stack.Â  It starts on the blocky section on the wall between "Submariner" andÂ "Black Crack" I believe. Â Go up the chunk, clean the left side of the roof and crimp up the almost-blank face. Â Look for a right-hand side-pull and an incredible reach.

content.description:
Crux is a balancy hand move 15 feet off the ground.  Good mix of moves and exposure many feet above the waves. 

  Route is short but worth lapping a few times to work on technique.
content.location: Left of plaque (on plaque wall).  Stays on the right side of the arete.

content.description: Climb corners and finish through notch.
content.location: Under right facing corner

content.description:
Start up corner, traverse out under the overhang then work your way up the ramp/corner. 

  Climbable in the rain.
content.location: Right in the middle of the main face, off of the most climber's left staple.

content.description: Straight up the corner between The Great Chimney and Black Crack.
content.protection: I don't know how well it protects on lead.  I only top-roped it.
content.location: Build an anchor and rap down.

content.description: Climb to a dike and continue up the arete.
content.location: Smaller notch right of the Staircase notch.

content.description: This route was pretty tricky for the grade
content.location: The Arete on the left of Yellow Wall.   Just Right of The Seastack

content.description: Bouldery start and follow face to top.
content.location: Start under airy arete left of wonder wall corner.

content.description: This is a nice route in a classic Otter Cliffs location. Start from a nice ledge just a few feet above the crashing waves; wet shoes are a real possibility! The climb ascends an obvious crack using face, and jam moves. The crux is down low, the climb eases off as you get higher.
content.protection: Cams to 3", nuts. Use gear to build an anchor at the top for TR setup.
content.location: At the far left/west side of the Sea Cave. Rap down (you'll need to build a gear anchor for the rappel; no bolts) to an intermediate large (10' x 20') ledge and set a TR anchor or lower down to the starting ledge.

content.description: Up left side of notch and copper colored rock.
content.location: Just left of notch.

content.description: Follow arete, through an overlap and then face just right of the arete.
content.location: At arete to the right of The Gallery

content.description: Perfect during lower tides, this large traverse can be found towards the beginning of Otter Cliffs.  It is easily over 100 feet long and probably about 20 feet high.  You will weave in and out of large pockets and there is no shortage of holds; you have a ton of rock to work with
content.protection: its a pretty easy traverse can be done with no pads or spotters, but they are encouraged due to the large and very rocky landing
content.location: Park at the very first lot for Otter Cliffs and proceed to hike the trail staying on the top of the cliffs.  About a half mile or so down the trail, you will see a large cliff jutting out into the sea at about a 45 degree angle.  Start on the far left side of the cliff and keep going until you reach the water

content.description: Climb to the right side of the alcove and top out.
content.location: Under an alcove (right side)

content.description:
NOTE: This route is a historical note. It is no longer the same route since the chockstone fell down. 

  Right side of Guillotine Wall if facing the water. Climb the corner at the bottom and finish in the chimney where the chockstone is midway up.
content.location: Otter Cliffs - Guillotine Wall

content.description: Climb face past an overlap using path of least resistance.
content.location: Left of offwidth

content.description:
good route up the right side of The Guillotine Alcove 

  Climb through notch and right facing corners to top.
Climb past a small triangular hole to a vertical crack and top out.
content.location: Under the small triangular hole

content.description: Fun timing with the tides leads to fantastic and varied climbing.  Liebacking, tricky problem solving through the roof, and crack climbing, or at least some stellar jams.
content.location: rappel in, south of the haystack.  Obvious, gaping right facing corner

content.description: Climb up, keeping left of the alcove.
content.location: Left of the alcove

content.description: Climb to the alcove and keep going.
content.location: Under the alcove

content.description: Steep face moves to a 10 foot finger to thin hand crack, face holds lead to top.
content.protection: There is no pro after the crack. Nuts and small cams with protect before that.   Fixed anchor on top.
content.location: Far left side of the wonder wall (facing the ocean)

content.description: Ascend a right facing crack up a steep wall, skirting the overhang to the left, or direct up through the overhang for a 5.9- variation.
content.protection: Fixed anchor at the top of the climb.
content.location: Ten feet to the left of Adair by the Sea.

content.description:
Most famous and heavily used climbing area in Acadia. Toprope or rappel in to climb here.

 Anchors are solid steel bars pounded into the top of the cliff because years of toproping here has killed many trees.

 Excellent place for beginners to learn about climbing, the beauty of nature, and placing gear in a wet crack.

 Beware high tides as your ropes will get soaked and your gear will be salt encrusted. the rock that the routes start on just gets underwater at the highest tide points. Tides change rapidly here, keep an eye on your time and check out the tide charts before you come.Â
